title: Ticket #2006: RFE: publish some additional performance-related stats in schedd ad
description:
Having the schedd publish some additional performance-related statistics would improve the ability of an admin to understand how the schedd and the pool in general are performing.

Some proposed additional classad statistic attributes:

  • Jobs submitted
  • Jobs started
  • Jobs completed/exited

  • Over some definable window, rates (jobs/sec) for above (+ way to define that window)

  • Job Exit code histogram
  • Shadow Exception counts

  • Job running times
  • Times spent waiting in job queue to start

  • Cumulative variations on above (i.e. over schedd lifetime)
remarks:
2011-Mar-29 16:10:47 by eje:
The attached patch "gt2006_schedd_stats.patch" defines the following: 

UpdateInterval: seconds between current schedd ad publish time and previous

JobsSubmitted: number of jobs submitted over most recent sampling window
JobSubmissionRate: rate of job submission (jobs/sec) over sampling window
JobsCompleted: number of jobs completed (successfully) over sampling window
JobCompletionRate: rate of successful job completions over window
JobsExited: number of jobs that exited (successful or otherwise) over window
ShadowExceptions: number of shadow exceptions over window
ExitCodeXXX: number of jobs exited with code XXX (100, 115, etc) over window

JobsSubmittedCum: number of jobs submitted over lifetime of schedd
JobsCompletedCum: number of jobs successfully completed over schedd lifetime
JobsExitedCum: number of jobs exited (successful or otherwise) over schedd lifetime
ShadowExceptionsCum: number of shadow exceptions over schedd lifetime
ExitCodeCumXXX: number of jobs exited with code XXX over schedd lifetime

WindowedStatWidth: The value of config param WINDOWED_STAT_WIDTH at the time this ad was published

JobsStartedCum: Number of jobs started over schedd lifetime
JobsStarted: Number of jobs started in stat window WINDOWED_STAT_WIDTH
JobStartRate: The rate (jobs/sec) of jobs starting in stat window

MeanTimeToStartCum: mean time a job waits in the schedd until first start, over schedd lifetime
MeanRunningTimeCum: mean running time for jobs in the schedd (wall-clock time), over schedd lifetime
SumTimeToStartCum: sum of job wait times to first start, over schedd lifetime
SumRunningTimeCum: sum of job running times over schedd lifetime

MeanTimeToStart: mean time a job waits in schedd until first start, over stat window
MeanRunningTime: mean running (wall-clock) time of jobs in schedd, over stat window

These are now published to all daemon ads, via dc_collector:
DetectedMemory: detected machine RAM
DetectedCpus: detected machine cpus/cores

2011-May-03 10:13:30 by nwp:
I reviewed the patch for #2006. I cannot find anything obviously wrong with it. Todd expressed concern with some of the names, especially ones that are close to existing attribute names, and the names ending in "...Cum". Also Todd has expressed some desire to see that attributes are properly scoped, but my understanding is that that is a long term project.

I am going to push this onto V7_7-publish_schedd_stats-branch and send this back to Erik to revise.

2011-May-10 08:26:00 by eje:
I'd like to get more clarity about what changes to make for inclusion -- my understanding is that name scoping is going to be tabled until classad support for namespaces.

On the schedd ad, I do not see any attribute names that seemed confusing to me. There was mention of confusion between "JobsExited" and "JobExited" however I do not see any occurrence of "JobExited" on the schedd or any other ad.

The other remaining issue was "Cum" --> "Cumulative." I propose making that change for inclusion, with name scoping to be addressed in the future with classad namespaces.

2011-Jun-06 16:53:59 by johnkn:
Regarding the Cum/Cumulative. I think it would be more likely to match naieve expectations if the windowed values had a prefix rather than the lifetime cumulative values having a suffix. I propose Recent as the prefix. But I think Cur or Current or Window would be fine.

So JobsSubmitted becomes RecentJobsSubmitted and JobsSubmittedCum becomes JobsSubmitted. I think someone who hadn't read this

Also. I think that some other name changes could make the names more clearly match the data they contain. I suggest. 

RecentStatWindowWidth: The value of config param WINDOWED_STAT_WIDTH at the time.
RecentJobsStarted: Number of jobs started in stat window WINDOWED_STAT_WIDTH
RecentJobStartedPerSec: The rate (jobs/sec) of jobs starting in stat window
RecentJobsSubmitted: number of jobs submitted over most recent sampling window
RecentJobsSubmittedPerSec: rate of job submission (jobs/sec) over sampling window
RecentJobsCompleted: number of jobs completed (successfully) over sampling window
RecentJobsCompletedPerSec: rate of successful job completions over window
RecentJobsExited: number of jobs that exited (successful or otherwise) over window
RecentShadowExceptions: number of shadow exceptions over window
RecentJobxExitedWithCodeXXX: number of jobs exited with code XXX (100, 115, etc) over window
RecentMeanJobTimeToStart: mean time a job waits in schedd until first start, over stat window
RecentMeanJobRunningTime: mean running (wall-clock) time of jobs in schedd, over stat window

JobsSubmitted: number of jobs submitted over lifetime of schedd
JobsStarted: Number of jobs started over schedd lifetime
JobsCompleted: number of jobs successfully completed over schedd lifetime
JobsExited: number of jobs exited (successful or otherwise) over schedd lifetime
ShadowExceptions: number of shadow exceptions over schedd lifetime
JobsExitedWithCodeXXX: number of jobs exited with code XXX over schedd lifetime this ad was published

MeanJobTimeToStart: mean time a job waits in the schedd until first start, over schedd lifetime
MeanJobRunningTime: mean running time for jobs in the schedd (wall-clock time), over schedd lifetime
TotalJobTimeToStart: sum of job wait times to first start, over schedd lifetime
TotalJobRunningTime: sum of job running times over schedd lifetime

Finally, use of minutes rather than seconds as the units of the window size strikes me as likely to cause confusion and errors.
